title: MAMMAL ASSOCIATIONS AND HABITATS OF THE FLATHEAD LAKE REGION, MONTANA
abstract: is bordered on the west by prairie, while on its eastern side there are mountains rising to more than 2,000 meters (7,000 ft.), and covered with coniferous forests up to the summits. The lake is at an altitude of 890 meters (2,930 ft.), and is due to glacial activity. During the summer of 1913 a period of seven weeks, June 17 to August 4, was spent in intensive study of the local distribution of the mammals around Flathead Lake. The region about the University of Montana Biological Station at Yellow Bay, on the eastern side of the lake, was studied most, but some trapping was done in the swamps at the southern end, and on Wild Horse Island near the western side of the lake. Also three days were spent on Mt. MacDougal (altitude about 7,600 feet), in the Swan Range, about 12 miles northeast of Big Fork. These situations gave a wide range of habitats and included the principal mammal environments of the region. However, relatively little information was secured about the mammals of the prairie on the western side of Flathead Lake. Special attention was directed to the determination of how closely the mammals are limited in distribution to the various kinds of vegetation. The classification of plant associations given by Whitford ('05) was followed in the main as a basis for work, but an attempt was made to carry on trapping and observation in every kind of habitat which seemed possibly to afford a different kind of environment for mammals. No opportunity was found to study the mammals of the cedar forests described by Whitford, nor the extensive meso-hydrophytic forests at the north end of Flathead Lake. It is realized that the time spent in the field work was too short to secure information on all the habitats of aft the mammals of the region, but for the common species it is believed that the habitat relations in the region about Yellow Bay were fairly well worked out. The associations recognized may be listed as follows: Open-water Bunchgrass Beach Buckbrush Marsh Mountain meadow Cottonwood-birch Alpine fir Englemann spruce-grand fir Talus slope Western larch-Douglas fir Aerial Lodgepole pine Clearing Yellow pine-Douglas fir Edificarian 1 No mammals found, omitted from habitat descriptions.

Only those species are listed of which specimens were collected or which on reliable authority are reported to occur in the neighborhood of Perornyscus maniculatus artemisiae, Sagebrush Deer-mouse, 4.

On the shores of Flathead Lake there is usually a fairly broad beach, covered by water in the spring and early summer, but exposed in late summer and fall. Much of the beach is gravelly, and strong waves beat upon it at times. In several sheltered coves the beach is sandy. Mud shores are found extensively at the south end of the lake, at the delta of the Flathead River, and at a few other places, but are usually covered by vegetation and are included in other habitats. A characteristic tree frequently found on rock or gravelly shores is the Rocky Mountain juniper (Juniperus scopulorum), which often attains considerable size. Willows grow scantily here and there in the water near shore, even though submerged a large part of the year.
Nearly everywhere considerable driftwood has been washed upon the beach.
Several shrews are reported to have been captured in the summer of 1912 about logs on the beach at Yellow Bay. A few deer-mice occur on this beach, especially about driftwood.

Numerous marshes and meadows occur along the edges of Flathead Lake, This content downloaded from 141.211.4.224 on Thu, 07 Oct 2021 17:59:05 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms especially on its southern and southeastern borders, about the smaller lakes of the region, and in places along the streams. These marshes are flooded during the spring and early summer, when the rise in the lake level may be as much as 15 feet. Late in summer the water-level falls and the marshes become uncovered. When the region was studied in the latter part of July, large areas of the marsh were still under water. The great fluctuation in water-level would seem to make these marshes a rather unfavorable habitat for most mammals.

Three distinct belts of vegetation can be distinguished in the large marshes in the southeastern part of Flathead Lake. In the wetter part of the marsh there are bays and lanes of open water, invaded by cat-tails, which form a rather wide belt. Next is a strip just out of water, or (in late July) still partially covered, where horsetails and sedges grow abundantly. In the drier part of the marsh near the forest border is a zone of grasses and sedges.

During the last week in July the Sawatch meadow-mouse was abundant in these large marshes. It was found in nearly equal numbers in the belt of horsetails and sedges and in the drier belt of grasses and sedges. The jumping-mouse was numerous at this time in the sedges and grass near the forest border. The mink, muskrat, and beaver are reported by residents to occur in these swamps, but none were observed by us. Dr. M. J. Elrod saw a moose feeding here in the summer of 1912. One navigator shrew was trapped July 19 at the edge of a small lake and marsh near the base of Mt. MacDougal.

Small areas of deciduous trees occur near Yellow Bay in strips near the lake shore and in the wet depressions near the mouths of the small streams.

This type of forest is temporary and exists because it can occupy the ground more quickly than the slower growing conifers, which eventually shade it out. The pine squirrel, found abundantly in the neighboring conifer forests, does not seem to be normally present in the deciduous type of forest, probably because of the absence of its usual pine seed food.

The deer of the region near Yellow Bay are reported by hunters to be mainly of a white-tailed variety, though black-tailed deer are said to occur on the Mission mountains farther south. However, the reports are too indefinite to admit of specific identification. No other females taken during the summer carried embryos. This indicates that young females may breed early in the same season in which they are born, and that the period between June 20 and August 1 is not a time when young are normally carried by the species in this locality.

Other mammals common in the larch and Douglas fir forests at Yellow Bay are the pine squirrel, which in July was feeding on the cones of the Douglas fir, and yellow-bellied chipmunks, two of which were taken in mouse traps. Signs of snowshoe hares and of deer were often found. A weasel was seen in this habitat by Edward Allen and W. L. Conway, students at the Biological Station. July 27, Mr. Conway saw a skunk near the shore of Flathead Lake; June 24, he saw two flying-squirrels at the edge of the laboratory clearing.

body_text.text: There is probably little difference between the mammals of the Douglas fir and of the larch, though not very much trapping was done in the latter. In a nearly pure larch forest near Yellow Bay the pine squirrel was often seen and one was taken; 5 deer-mice were taken; and the remains of one snowshoe hare were found in the road, where it had been eaten by sonie carnivore, likely a bob-cat. In nearly pure Douglas fir forest near Yellow Bay 13 deer-mice, 1 red-backed mouse, 2 jumping mice, and 1 pine squirrel were taken; and several other pine squirrels and yellow-bellied chipmunks were seen. The remainder of the mammals listed from the habitat were taken in mixed stands.

Extensive areas of brush occur on the upper parts of the mountains a the eastern side of Flathead Lake. Most of it is on burned tracts, thou portion is on rocky slopes which seem never to have been forested. The vegetation is made up of several different kinds of shrubs, of which the alders, Alnus sp., and buckbrush, Ceanothus velutinus, are most characteristic. The height and density of the brush varies greatly. In some places it is low, and the ground is covered principally by annuals or grasses; while elsewhere shrubs occupy the ground to the exclusion of everything else, and grow to heights of ten to twenty feet. Where the ground is very rocky, the shrubs are widely scattered, while in good soil they may form a dense thicket.

Columbian ground-squirrels were abundant in the drier parts, though their burrows were usually found near brush or clumps of trees. White-bellied chipmunks were numerous. Signs of snowshoe hare and tracks of deer and mountain-goat were noted.

Near the summit of Mt. MacDougal are very extensive talus slopes, loose broken rocks of all sizes, on which trees do not grow and shrubs are rare.
However, grasses and herbs are common, while under the rocks are many places of refuge for small mammals.

On these talus slopes in the third week of July hoary marmots were heard a number of times; several pikas were seen and one collected; a few Columbian ground-squirrels and white-bellied chipmunks were seen; and numerous fresh signs of snowshoe hare, deer, and mountain-goat were noted. It is probable that several species of mice are members of the association also, but no trapping was done.

On still evenings, when mosquitoes were abundant over the lake, bats were very numerous for some distance from shore. There are only a few clearings near Yellow Bay, and these confined to the vicinity of the lake. Some of these clearings are being farmed, others are growing up to brush or to young forests.

Yellow-bellied chipmunks are common in the brush of the clearings. One ground-squirrel was taken and several seen on cultivated ground of a farm near Yellow Bay. In late June seven deer-mice were trapped in an open grove of yellow pine saplings growing in an old clearing.

Houses and buildings are few in the region studied about Yellow Bay.

Several deer-mice were trapped in the laboratory building and in the adjacent kitchen. Two yellow-bellied chipmunks were trapped in some old log buildings beside the laboratory. A few woodrats also lived in these log buildings, and a half-grown female was trapped July 4; the previous winter the woodrats had built a nest in one of the boats in the boat house. Under some loose boards beside the laboratory building Dr. Elrod found two Merriam meadowmice on July 3.

Three faunal areas are represented in the Flathead Lake Region: one confined to the cold parts of the higher mountains; one consisting of the forested lower slopes of the mountains and the shores of Flathead Lake; and the third the prairie to the west and south of the lake. Each of these areas is characterized by the presence of peculiar species of mammals and by the dominance of different kinds of habitats. Bangs flying-squirrel, Glaitcomys sabrinus bangsi.

body_text.text: The faunal areas near Flathead Lake seem to correspond closely to the belts of life recognized on the mountains of south-central Idaho. There are some apparent differences in the species of mammals restricted to the corresponding zones in the two places, but the collecting in both localities was of brief duration, and when the faunas are more completely known many of the discrepancies will probably disappear.

body_text.text: The most distinctly marked mammal associations in the Flathead Lake region are the ones whose habitats are most different in character. These are the marsh, bunchgrass, and talus-slope associations. In each of these associations is included one or more species of mammals not found in other associations and one or more species there reach their greatest abundance.

The various kinds of forest habitats of the same faunal area, on the other hand, do not show very striking differences. For example, the differences between the Engelmann spruce-grand fir mammal association and the westtern larch-Douglas spruce mammal association near Flathead Lake are differences only in the comparative abundance of certain species, and every species found in the one habitat will probably be found at least occasionally in the other. The differences between the mammals of the western larch stands and those of the Douglas fir stands are still less marked. The kind of forest is evidently of much less importance in limiting the local distribution of mammals than the presence or absence of forest.

There are, of course, marked differences between the mammal faunas of deciduous forests and conifer forests, between moist grand fir forests and dry yellow pine forests, and between lowland forests and mountain-top forests.

In these cases, however, it is difficult to determine whether the kind of forest limits the distribution of the mammals or whether both forests and mammals are limited in distribution by the same or similar environmental factors.

In many habitats the vegetation is the dominant factor in the mammal environment, and even in those habitats where the vegetation is not the most important part of the environment it forms in general a good index to the distribution of the mammal associations.
Bailey, Vernon

Prairie is extensively developed on exposed slopes west and south of
Flathead Lake, where it occupies most of the territory. On Wild Horse
Island, near the western side of the lake, there are large areas of prairie on
the southwestern slopes of the hills. The most significant plants of the prairie
on this island are the wheat bunchgrass, Agropyron spicatum; sagebrush,
Artemisia frigid; and the large-leaved herb, balsam root, Balsamorhiza
sagittata.

On the northeastern side of the Swan Range, near the summit of Mt.
MacDougal, there are extensive mountain meadows. Some of these are
nearly level, while others are steep. Here the snow lies until late in summer,
and the ground is cold and wet. In late summer quick-growing herbs appear
in abundance. There are sometimes a few low shrubs, but trees are absent
except in isolated clumps.

TABREF5.text: Similar faunal areas were found by Merriam (1891) in the mountains of Idaho. There the prairie is placed in the Neutral or Transition Zone; the lower area of forest is designated the Canadian or Douglas Fir Zone; and the colder forested area is called the Hudsonian or Spruce Zone.This content downloaded from 141.211.4.224 on Thu, 07 Oct 2021 17:59:05 UTC All use subject to https://about.jstor.org/terms In the Flathead Lake region the faunal area corresponding to the Hudsonian or Spruce Zone of Idaho was studied only on Mt. MacDougal where it is made up of the talus slope association, the mountain meadow association, and the alpine fir association. The Engelmann spruce forest of the higher mountains belongs here also. Species of mammals found only in this faunal area are the Montana hoary marmot, Marnota caligata nivaria; white-bellied chipmunk, Eutacmias umbrinus; Rocky Mountain pika, Ochotona princess; and Missoula mountain-goat, Oreanlnos montanus missoulae. The faunal area characterized by prairie was not carefully studied in the vicinity of Flathead Lake. In it the bunchgrass habitat is known to be dominant, though what other habitats and associations occur in the strictly prairie region is not known with certainty.
